abstract.text: A string of text that manages data, layout, and stylistic information for ranges of characters to support rendering.
Add high-performance 2D content with smooth animations to your app, or create a game with a high-level set of 2D game-based tools.
3D SceneKit content drawn as a flattened sprite.
A source of various particle effects.
Options for aligning text horizontally.
A graphical element that draws text.
The attributed string displayed by the label.
The blend mode used to draw the label into the parent’s framebuffer.
An alternative to the font color that can be used for animations.
A floating-point value that describes how the color is blended with the font color.
The color of the label.
The font used for the text in the label.
The size of the font used in the label.
The horizontal position of the text within the node.
Initializes a new label object with an attributed text string.
Initializes a new label object with a specified font.
Initializes a new label object with a text string.
Initializes a new label object.
Determines the line-break mode for multiple lines.
Determines the number of lines to draw.
The width, in screen points, after which line-break mode should be applied.
The string that the label node displays.
The vertical position of the text within the node.
Options for aligning text vertically.
The base class of all SpriteKit nodes.
A mathematical shape that can be stroked or filled.
An image or solid color.
A two-dimensional array of images.
A graphical element that plays video content.
Draw text in your scene, such as a health indicator or a “Game Over” banner, by using a label node.
Learn about the fundamental properties that provide a foundation for all other nodes.
Structure your nodes for maximum performance.
Distort the child nodes of an effect node by applying a warping effect.

doc://com.apple.spritekit/documentation/.title: Warping SpriteKit Content By Using an Effect Node

abstract.text: A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A set of methods for converting between different frames of reference on a screen.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
An object that can become focused.
The container responsible for providing geometric context to focus items within a given focus environment.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
Configure these properties to control line-breaking behavior.
Change how a label uses an alpha value, such as additive blending, that results in the label being brighter than it was before.
Configure these properties to control line-breaking behavior.
Change how a label uses an alpha value, such as additive blending, that results in the label being brighter than it was before.
